journal-meta.journal-title: The Journal of Strain Analysis for Engineering Design

title-group.article-title: Application of an extended Rusinek–Klepaczko constitutive model to predict the mechanical behavior of 6082-T6 aluminum under Taylor impact test conditions

article-meta.aff: 1Institute of Fundamental Technological Research, Warsaw, Poland

author-notes.corresp: Wojciech Moćko, Institute of Fundamental Technological Research, 5B Pawińskiego Street, 02-106 Warsaw, Poland. Email: wmocko@ippt.gov.pl

abstract.p: The application of an extended Rusinek–Klepaczko constitutive equation to predict the mechanical response of 6082-T6 aluminum under the Taylor impact test conditions was presented in this article. The numerical results obtained in the study were verified through a comparison with the experimental data extracted from the Taylor anvil-on-rod impact experiments. It was concluded that the extended Rusinek–Klepaczko constitutive model predicts the behavior of the tested aluminum alloy under applied loading conditions with satisfactory accuracy. Moreover, it was found that the plastic wave phenomenon in this material is very limited and that there was no region of constant plastic wave velocity. Strain rates up to 1.6 × 104 s−1 were recorded during the Taylor impact experiments; therefore, this value may be set as the upper limit of the extended Rusinek–Klepaczko model for the alloy, which was validated with the anvil-on-rod experiment.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The accurate prediction of the behavior of structures under extreme impact or explosive loadings requires a constitutive model that describes material behavior at high strain rates. There are two types of these constitutive models: empirically based (i.e. Johnson and Cook1) and physically based (i.e. Zerilli and Armstrong model2). The former one fits an assumed constitutive equation to experimental data, whereas the latter one takes the microstructural behavior of the material into account when formulating the constitutive equation.

An example of a physically based model is the Rusinek–Klepaczko (RK) equation, which includes effects from strain hardening, the thermal activation process, and changes in the Young’s modulus due to temperature.

Until nowadays, the RK model was mainly applied to describe mechanical properties of various steel grades,3–7 whereas a number of articles dealing with aluminum alloy modeling using the RK equation are limited.8,9 In some parts of those works, investigators focused their attention on maintaining a good agreement between experimental and model-based stress–strain curves, taking into account some phenomena occurring during plastic deformation, that is, thermal activation,4 adiabatic conditions,4 instabilities5 viscous-drag effect,6 and negative strain rate sensitivity.8 Moreover, a few articles concerning perforation of the steel sheet together with finite element simulation may be found.4,7,10 In those simulations, the RK equation was applied to model viscoplastic response of material at high strain rates. This article presents application of the RK model extended by term related to a viscous-drag effect (extended Rusinek–Klepaczko (ERK) model) to simulate the Taylor test using a finite element method (FEM). It is worth emphasizing that until now it is hard to find in the references an example of numerical analysis of impact into a rigid wall of a cylindrical specimen made of material defined by the RK model.

In the previous works of other authors,6 the ERK model, taking into account a viscous-drag effect, was calibrated with data collected from a split Hopkinson bar for strain rates up to 104 s−1. However, even higher strain rates should be considered in some special applications, that is, turbine blade impact or armor penetration. Therefore, the ERK model for 6082-T6 aluminum was calibrated using the results obtained for strain rates up to 105 s−1 by applying the miniaturized direct impact compression test method.9

It is hard to estimate a quality of ERK constitutive equation incorporating viscous-drag term only by comparison of the shape of calculated and experimental stress–strain curves. Therefore, in this article, the authors use the Taylor impact methodology to validate the ERK model that was calibrated previously.9 The validation was carried out by comparison of the estimated and measured values of the specimen outer profile after the test, the dynamic yield point calculated on the basis of Taylor theory, the velocity decrease of the specimen’s free end during impact, and the process of plastic wave propagation inside the specimen.

The Taylor impact test was originally developed to determine the dynamic yield strength of materials.11 More recently, the Taylor impact technique has been used to validate numerical codes used to simulate plastic deformation. The methodology developed by Taylor uses the characteristic dimensions of the specimen to analyze the mechanical properties. Later works by other researchers12–14 developed the impact phenomena model, which enables a more precise determination of the yield point of the tested material for deformation rates from 103 s−1 to 104 s−1. Since large gradients of temperatures and strains may be observed during the plastic deformation of a specimen with high strain rates, the Taylor impact test is often used to validate constitutive equations calibrated previously with other experimental methods.15,16

A very important problem, which may be considered during Taylor impact experiments, is the proper analysis of the plastic wave propagation during deformation. Modern measurement methods, such as high-speed cameras17 or the FEM,18 make it possible to verify the previously developed plastic wave propagation models.19,20

The Taylor test results for aluminum alloys with low elongation and low work hardening may be found in the literature;21,22 however, those works mainly consider the initiation and propagation of material damage. There is a lack of publications that analyze plastic wave propagation in aluminum alloys. Therefore, the authors of this article include an assessment of plastic wave propagation in a specimen of 6082-T6 aluminum during a rigid wall impact. The initial velocity of the projectile was selected in order to prevent clearly visible material damage.
To summarize, the goals of the presented study were as follows.

list-item.p: The validation of the ERK model coefficients for 6082-T6 aluminum that were calibrated previously9,23 using a miniaturized direct impact compression test and the Hopkinson bar method.24–26
The analysis of the plastic wave propagation during the impact of a cylindrical specimen into a rigid wall.

sec.title: Taylor test
sec.p: The Taylor test configuration is presented in Figure 1, where L denotes the initial specimen length, V0 is the initial velocity, L1 is the final specimen length, and X is the length of the nondeformed section of the specimen after impact. The dynamic yield point may be determined with the following formula proposed by Taylor

caption.p: Taylor test configuration.

sec.p: From the theory of the cylindrical Taylor test, the deformation rate should be discussed in detail because the value of the deformation rate varies in the subsequent deformation stages. Because of this variation in the strain rate, a definition of the average strain rate must be introduced in order to determine the strain rate during an impact test. The average strain rate is defined as follows

Owing to many simplifications in the Taylor model, various improvements were made to the impact theory in the Taylor test. First, Taylor himself proposed a modification of equation (1) by introducing a correction coefficient to diminish the influence of the assumption of uniform de-acceleration of the free edge of the projectile. Denoting the correction coefficient as Ycorr/Y, the dependence introduced by Taylor has the form
where a, K, and Cp are defined as follows

The Taylor anvil-on-rod impact experiments presented here were carried out with the laboratory apparatus developed at the Military University of Technology (Figure 2). Flat-ended cylinders were impacted normally onto a smooth-faced rigid target to induce plastic deformation. The tests were conducted on Al 6068 cylinders with 12.05 mm diameter and 48 mm length.

caption.p: Arrangement for the Taylor anvil-on-rod impact tests: (a) 12.1-mm-diameter single-stage gas gun and (b) clamping assembly.

sec.p: A 12.1-mm diameter, smooth-bore, single-stage gas gun was used to launch the Taylor cylindrical specimen (Figure 2(a)). The gas gun consists of two main components: the 2.4-m length barrel and the pressure system that is capable of providing pressures up to 200 bar. Helium was used as the pressuring gas. The impact velocities of the cylindrical specimens ranged from 202 to 355 m/s, while the breech pressure varied from 20 to 60 bar. Cylinders were fired without sabots onto a large disc target made of maraging steel (grade 350) with hardness of 57 Rockwell C Hardness (HRC). The disc target, 80 mm in diameter and 30-mm thick, was mounted on a clamping assembly (Figure 2(b)), which ensured the normal orientation of the target with respect to the barrel axis. The impact surface of the anvil was ground to a smooth finish and was lubricated before each test with molybdenum disulfide (MoS2).

The impact between the specimen and the anvil was recorded with a Phantom v12 high-speed digital camera. To obtain high-quality images and to ensure satisfactorily accurate measurements of the impact velocity and of the changes in the rod geometry during the dynamic deformation, a shadow method of optical observation was used. This method consists of recording the shadow of a cylindrical specimen on a highlighted background, which is illuminated with a Dedocool lighting system that allows the concentration of an intense amount of light over a small area.

More details concerning the ERK model and its calibration procedure may be found in previous works.3,27–30

The coefficients of the ERK constitutive model were calibrated with the experimental data shown in Tables 1 and 2. The values of the drag-stress component coefficients χ and α are slightly different from those used in earlier publications9 due to new experimental data that were obtained using the miniaturized direct impact compression test (MDICT) method. The new results were acquired at higher strain rates than in previous works and, as a consequence, enable more precise estimates of the coefficients of the drag-stress component.

caption.p: Constitutive model parameters determined for 6082-T6 aluminum.
Physical parameters of the aluminum alloy.

sec.p: The experimental flow stress presented in Figure 3 was determined from compression and Taylor impact tests, and the theoretical flow stress curve was calculated with the ERK model. Figure 4(a) shows the stress–strain curves of 6082-T6 aluminum measured in a wide range of strain rates with the various methods described earlier, whereas Figure 4(b) presents the stress–strain curves based on the ERK model.

caption.p: Plastic flow stress of 6082-T6 aluminum at various strain rates.
RK: Rusinek–Klepaczko; SHPB: split Hopkinson pressure bar; DICT: direct impact compression test method.
Stress–strain curves of 6082-T6 aluminum and the dynamic yield point obtained using Taylor theory: (a) experimental and (b) determined using the ERK model.
RK: Rusinek–Klepaczko.

sec.title: Results of the Taylor test experiment
sec.p: The Taylor test was carried out according to methodology described in section “Taylor test” for 6082-T6 aluminum with various initial projectile velocities. It is assumed that the lowest initial velocity for a Taylor impact is equal to 200 m/s; therefore, the experiment was set up to obtain a similar initial velocity. The actual lowest impact velocity, measured with a high-speed camera, was equal to 203.9 m/s. In the subsequent stages of testing, the velocity was increased until clearly visible cracks were present in the deformed material. Since the scope of this work was the analysis of the plastic behavior of 6082-T6 aluminum under impact loadings, test results above 280 m/s were not taken into consideration due to the visible material damage. It is planned to analyze this damage phenomenon in further works. The test results from five initial projectile velocities were presented and considered.

The specimen dimensions before and after impact, the dynamic yield point, and the strain rate determined using Taylor methodology were presented in Table 3. The dimensions of the specimens were measured using a coordinate measuring machine. The dynamic yield point calculated with the Taylor theory yields results, which are in good agreement with the results from the Hopkinson bar experiments (Figure 3). The increase in initial velocity of the projectile results in a negligible change in the dynamic yield point value. Images of a cylindrical specimen in the “zero” condition and specimens after the impact test are shown in Figure 5. An increase of the initial velocity causes the enlargement of the specimen “foot” diameter and shortens the nondeformed part of the specimen.

caption.p: The experimental results of the Taylor theory analysis.
View of the final geometry of the specimens after the Taylor impact test.

sec.p: The subsequent stages of the experiment that were recorded with a high-speed digital camera31 are depicted in Figure 6. In some pictures, the area near the impact zone is blurred by dust from the projectile and target plate lubrication of Teflon spray and molybdenum disulfide (MoS2). The lubrication was applied to prevent friction and the halting of the specimen in the gas launcher. The first image for all of the recorded videos (t = 0) shows the moment of initial contact between the projectile and the anvil. The last picture was taken 60 µs after the initial contact, when there is no more plastic deformation in the material. The specimen shortening and the “foot” enlargement may be then analyzed.

caption.p: Subsequent stages of the specimens’ deformation during the Taylor impact tests with various initial velocities.

sec.p: For comparative purposes, the geometry of the specimens after the Taylor test was accurately measured with the measuring comparator Starrett 400 (Figure 7(a)). Additionally, the plastic deformation of the specimens was analyzed from the recorded videos; however, only specimen No. 9 was analyzed with this methodology (Figure 8(a)) due to the dust that covers the specimen foot in all other cases. Finally, the de-acceleration of the free end of the specimen during impact was determined using video tracking (Figure 9(a)).

caption.p: Shapes of the specimen contours after the Taylor impact with various initial velocities: (a) experimental results, (b) FEM results, and (c) difference between experiment and calculation.
FEM: finite element method.

Shapes of the specimen No. 9 contours at subsequent stages of deformation during the Taylor impact test with an impact velocity of 281 m/s: (a) experimental results, (b) FEM results, and (c) difference between experiment and calculation.
FEM: finite element method.

Velocity profiles of the free end of the specimen during the Taylor impact test with various initial velocities: (a) experimental results, (b) FEM results, and (c) difference between experiment and calculation.
FEM: finite element method.

sec.title: FEM simulation of the Taylor test impact
sec.p: The deformation of the Taylor specimen deformation was numerically analyzed using Abaqus/Explicit. Other examples of Taylor impact numerical analysis using smooth particle hydrodynamics method may be found in references.32 The axially symmetric model consisted of 3200 CAX4R elements of 0.3 mm length with reduced integration and hourglass control enabled. The initial velocity was declared with an initial field, and the impact wall was declared to be rigid.

The calculated strain distribution inside the specimen for various initial projectile velocities is shown in Figure 10. In order to compare the results, the contours for all the experiments have the same scale. It may be observed that an increase in the impact velocity causes larger strains near the impact zone. For an initial velocity of 204 m/s, the maximum strain value is 0.68, whereas an initial velocity of 280 m/s has a maximum strain value that is greater than 1.00.

caption.p: Strain distribution inside the specimen after the Taylor impact experiment with various initial velocities.
PEEQ: equivalent plastic strain

sec.p: The propagation of the plastic wave along the length of specimen No. 9 (V0 = 280 m/s) in the FEM simulation is shown in Figure 11. It can be seen that the region of large deformation, where the strain exceeds a value of 0.5, is very narrow. This behavior is caused by the limited work hardening effect for 6082-T6 aluminum at high strains, which limits the propagation of the plastic wave. Plastic waves of lower strain values, that is, 0.1, propagate deeper inside the specimen material. This behavior of the plastic wave propagation can also be explained by analyzing the shape of the stress–strain curve for 6082-T6 aluminum: the tangential modulus for small strains is higher than that for large strains, causing larger wave propagation for lower values of plastic deformations.

caption.p: Plastic wave propagation inside specimen No. 9 during subsequent deformation stages.
PEEQ: equivalent plastic strain.

sec.p: The final shape of the Taylor specimen profiles determined with the FEM simulation for various initial velocities is shown in Figure 7(b). It may be observed that the length of undeformed part of the specimen is similar to experimental results; however, the numerically estimated diameter of the deformed “foot” section is smaller than the experimental results. The difference between real and calculated specimen outline is presented in Figure 7(c). The reason for such a discrepancy may be related to microdamages that occur during large plastic deformations and lead to material softening.21 In this analysis, the damage initiation and evolution was not considered. The accurate results of the specimen dimensions from the Taylor analysis are presented in Table 4.

caption.p: The results specification of the Taylor theory analysis—results of FEM simulation.

fn.p: FEM ERK: finite element method extended Rusinek–Klepaczko.

sec.p: Contour of the specimen No. 9 calculated using FEM simulation at subsequent stages of plastic deformation is shown in Figure 8(b). The difference between experimental and calculated data is presented in Figure 8(c). It may be observed that numerical model slightly underestimates the “foot” diameter at all deformation stages. The probable reason of such behavior may be related to material microdamage,21 which was not considered in this simulation.

De-acceleration of the specimen’s free end calculated using FEM shows good agreement with experimental data (Figure 9(b)). The discrepancy between particular curves of the same initial velocity is lower than 10 m/s.

sec.title: Analysis of the experimental and simulation results obtained with Taylor theory
sec.p: The simulation and experimental results of the Taylor theory and FEM analyses were compared in Figure 12. The strain rate values show good agreement in the whole range of the initial projectile velocities. The discrepancies between the experimental and simulation data are all less than 5%, and they do not depend on the initial velocity. The differences in the dynamic yield stress determined with both techniques vary from 3% to 10%; however, their values increase with the initial velocity.

caption.p: Comparison of experimental and FEM simulation results: (a) strain rate and (b) dynamic yield point.
FEM: finite element method; ERK: extended Rusinek–Klepaczko.

sec.title: Analysis of the plastic wave propagation during impact
sec.p: The velocity of the mechanical wave propagation in a given solid material may be calculated on the basis of tangential modulus14 in the following way
and

According to equation (8), the elastic wave propagates with the constant speed C0, which depends on the Young’s modulus and density of the material, while the plastic wave speed Cp is a function of the plastic flow stress–strain curve slope θ. The tangential modulus is a function of the plastic strain because the stress–strain curves of many materials are not linear. As a consequence, the velocity of the plastic wave propagation is dependent on the level of plastic deformation. The slope angle of the plastic part of the stress–strain curve is smaller than that of the elastic part; thus, an elastic wave moves with a higher speed than a plastic wave. Moreover, the velocity of the plastic wave propagation decreases with strain value. The mechanical wave velocity of 6082-T6 aluminum was determined from the data presented in Figure 4 using equations (8) and (9) and is shown in Figure 13. It may be observed that the elastic deformation wave velocity is close to reference data for this alloy, whereas the wave propagation velocity decreases in the plastic strain zone. The weak work hardening effect for 6082-T6 aluminum results in a low slope angle of the plastic flow stress–strain curve, causing low and limited propagation of the plastic wave.

caption.p: Velocity of mechanical wave propagation in 6082-T6 aluminum.

sec.p: Figure 14 shows the evolution of the off-axial strain during the Taylor experiment and the FEM simulation for specimen No. 9 at subsequent stages of deformation. The plastic wave propagation was estimated (Figure 15) on the basis of time and axial position values taken at given strains. Figure 15(a) shows the displacement of the plastic wave front along the specimen axis at strain values equal to 0.1, 0.2, and 0.3. Figure 15(b) presents the speed profile of the plastic wave estimated at the given strain values and at subsequent deformation time. It may be observed that due to very limited plastic wave propagation in 6082-T6 aluminum, it is hard to find the region of the constant wave velocity that was reported in other works.17,33 It may be seen from Figure 13 that the theoretical plastic wave velocity determined from the stress–strain curve at strains equal to 0.1 is less than 400 m/s. It is confirmed in Figure 15(b), where Cp is equal to 200 m/s at early stages of deformation for a strain value of 0.1.

caption.p: The displacement of the plastic wave front at a given strain during impact: (a) experiment and (b) numerical modeling.
FEM: finite element method.
Plastic wave propagation during the Taylor impact experiment: (a) wave front displacement and (b) wave velocity.
FEM: finite element method.

sec.title: Strain rate distribution during the Taylor impact
sec.p: Figure 16 shows the strain rate histogram at subsequent stages of the Taylor impact experiment determined using the FEM. The average strain rate calculated for specimen No. 9 according to the Taylor theory is equal to 4.7 × 103 s−1; however, a much wider range of strain rate may be found analyzing the histogram. The range of the observed strain rates decreases with time from 1.6 × 104 s−1 at the early deformation stages to 3.0 × 103 s−1 near the end of the impact. In the middle of the deformation process at t = 32 µs, the maximum of the strain rate curve has a value of about 5.0 × 103 s−1, which matches the Taylor theory.

caption.p: The strain rate histogram inside specimen No. 9 in the subsequent deformation stages.
FEM: finite element method.

sec.title: Summary
sec.p: The following conclusions may be drawn from the research presented in this article.

list-item.p: The simulation of the Taylor impact in Abaqus/Explicit with the ERK equation as a plasticity model shows good agreement with the experiments. The differences between the simulation and the Taylor theory results for the dynamic yield stress and strain rate are less than 10% and 5%, respectively.
During the Taylor impact, strain rates up to 1.6 × 104 s−1 were found; therefore, the analyzed ERK constitutive model may be validated within this range of deformation rates.
The plastic wave propagation phenomenon in 6082-T6 aluminum is very limited due to the small level of work hardening observed in this material.
